file_content.text: If you want me to do something, maybe give me a hint?
You may have doubts, but I can beat you in a staring contest.
I rather like your ship; not exactly military, but it'll be nice not sleeping in a thermosuit.
Once we're underway, you'll bring me up to speed on my duties, sir? Show me the tricks of undercover work?
You're embarking on a new career. No nostalgia for your old life?
You're very eager to move on.
None, sir. If I'm here, I intend to commit myself.
I look forward to training you personally, Ensign.
[Flirt] It'll be a pleasure.
I was afraid you'd leave it to the Rattataki.
I'll make sure you're brought up to speed, Ensign.
I'd be glad to train you.
I won't have time to hold your hand. You'll follow my orders and be glad of it.
This isn't a classroom.
Of course. I'll try to watch and learn.
I probably ought not to bring this up, but there is the matter of my... talents.
If I'm operating in the Empire, there's the chance the Sith will find out what I can do. They wouldn't be pleased.
If your talents become an issue, we'll deal with it then.
I'll keep that in mind.
As part of my crew, you have my protection.
You're safe with us.
Understood, sir. In the meantime, I intend to make myself irreplaceable.
If the Sith come for you, I plan to cooperate.
That's your problem.
Then I'll have to make myself irreplaceable, just in case. Sir.
Sir. I want you to be the first to know--I've declined to join the Toxi-Trooper Brigade on Quesh.
I received a personalized transfer offer from Major Yanus a few days ago; my time on Hoth flagged me as hostile-environment capable.
I didn't realize you were unhappy here.
You were considering leaving?
I'm not--but how often does a girl get a chance to fight in the chemical mines? It could make my career.
You couldn't tear yourself away from your husband, could you?
[Flirt] Bet you'd miss me.
No, sir. Tempting as the opportunity was.
"Hostile-environment capable," hmm? Next, you'll be earning the Medal of Progress.
I'm very impressed, Ensign.
If you'll put in the recommendation, sir.
I'm sure the chemical mines of Quesh could use someone like you.
Maybe you'd be better off.
I appreciate your faith, as always, sir.
There really was a time when I'd have considered it--for the promotion, for the sake of hiding--not so much anymore.
I'm proud to stand with you and fight for the Empire. Until the end.
I'm proud to have you at my side.
You're a fine officer.
Thank you, sir.
I appreciate your dedication, but you're under no obligation to stay.
If you ever need to leave....
I'm well aware, but thank you.
Now, I believe we had a mission of some sort. Shall we?
You think "the end" is coming so soon?
That's a little downbeat.
The end of the fighting is all I meant. But even so.
You wanted to talk?
I was just thinking about when we met. It was much colder, as I recall, and the aristocra was not entirely thrilled.
I thought you'd be gone in a week--and you were, but somehow you dragged me along.
I came to you out of an ambush in the snow, and there you were... glowing.
That first meeting was lovely.
Was I?
I was the mysterious Cipher agent. You couldn't let me go.
You were eager to follow me.
I'm not going to respond to that.
You were an irritant I didn't need on a delicate mission.
I thought I'd be rid of you.
And I got you what you needed.
Do you ever wonder about the future? Where the likes of us will stand in five, ten... fifty years?
I imagine myself with my wife at my side. What about you?
I'd like to be married.
I can imagine you that way, too.
Was that a proposal, sir?
Yes, it was.
If it was, would you say yes?
Only if you want it to be.
Yes. Yes, I would.
I'm sorry, but no.
We can't control what's coming, but we can appreciate what we have. And we have a great deal together.
We're happy now. It's enough.
We do. But tradition and stability have their merits, too.
Doing things properly... it means a lot, doesn't it?
Tradition's important to you.
Yes, it does.
And I know there are reasons we can't be together officially, formally--I'm not stupid, I just--you know.
We could still be engaged.
Raina Temple. Will you marry me?
Yes. Yes, I will marry you.
We don't have to do it on record--I realize there are consequences to making that sort of thing public.
But I can wait. And in the meantime....
In the meantime, we've got a wedding to plan, and a whole life after that.
We plan for the future.
We do, at that. I love you.
In the meantime, so far as I'm concerned, we're man and wife.
It will be real for me.
I love you, sir. Wrong-headed as you are sometimes.
Whatever comes, I always will.
In the meantime, let's focus on our jobs, and not our dreams.
We've got work to do.
I can live with that, sir.
I'm not sure I do know.
Sorry, I don't understand.
We're not going to marry.
I'll always care for you, but a proposal isn't in the plan.
Let's leave it at that, then, and get back to work.
There's not much room for tradition or stability in our lives. Not today, anyway.
Maybe one day, you'll have it.
No. And that won't change anytime soon.
Stability makes us careless. Vulnerable. One of the burdens we live with.
We'll never have stability.
Yes. I'm sorry that's how you see it.
In ten years, we may both be dead. In fifty--best not to think about it.
The future is a dark place.
I suppose I'll have to live with that. You're a puzzle, sir.
Sir! If I could have your attention.
Given what the crew's survived lately, I've decided we ought to celebrate with a night out. You should come along. For morale.
We could all use a chance to relax. Count me in.
That's an excellent idea.
I didn't know you were getting along so well with everyone.
You socialize with the crew?
Frankly, you and I are the only sane ones aboard--but I have to at least make an effort.
Come on. You can protect me from Doctor Lokin...
This isn't exactly a joyous occasion, Ensign.
There's nothing to celebrate.
No, it's not.
If there's anything I've learned, it's that this job is relentless--and if you see a chance to boost spirits, you need to take it. Consider it, sir.
How are things with you?
Excellent, sir--I just heard Lord Ulios is conducting another opera, and I'm looking forward to the holoplayback.
You know, it's been a while since we discussed it, but I believe you were going to take me out to dinner.
Just say the word. Did you have somewhere in mind?
Ready when you are.
There's a fantastic Mandalorian restaurant in Kaas City--I'm half-allergic to the dumplings, and I still love it.
But... anywhere in the galaxy will suffice, if the company is right.
Is this the best time for an outing?
You want to go out here? Now?
You don't have to dress up or spring for the best wine.
I just want your company awhile; somewhere we can be people. Come on.
...and that is the only time I ever went barefoot in the garden.
I do like you, sir. I don't want to lose you on some nameless satellite somewhere.
I promise, I don't intend to die any time soon.
You aren't going to lose me.
Sometimes intent isn't what matters.
That's a bit sudden. And pessimistic.
Why bring that up?
I'm not an optimistic person.
I'm sorry, I don't mean to bring us down--it really has been a wonderful evening....
Very few operatives survive until retirement. Get used to the idea.
It's always a risk.
Always comforting. I'm sorry--it really was a wonderful evening, but... well.
Raina--you mean the world to me.
Listen to me--I love you.
I love you, and nothing will come between us.
Thanks to our brilliant complementary tactics?
I love you, too. It's good to say it.
There's still time. We could take a walk, enjoy our privacy awhile....
[Flirt] We're not done yet.
...take our minds off trouble?
You know I'd like that. But for now... let's stop here. I want to remember this.
We both have a lot of work to do. Let's get back to it.
Let's end it here.
Of course, sir. Best not to linger on these things.
We'll have to save it for another time. Is there anything urgent?
We've got other business.
No, sir. Not today.
Sir. Doctor Lokin was just telling me stories about my father from his Intelligence days. All lies, I think, but that's all right.
What would you say if I brought some personal items on-board? I haven't played the melodium for years, but lately I've had the urge.
You never told me you played the melodium.
You're a musician, now?
Well, I'm not exactly proud of it.
You sound more upbeat than last time we talked.
Glad you're feeling better.
We do difficult things for the Empire. I know that.
But I did realize... maybe it's time I stopped spending all day, every day on-duty. The fourteen hour shift is enough.
Don't distract the crew, and no music while I'm in a briefing.
Just keep the noise down.
I can accommodate you there. Thank you, sir.
It's done--I'm back.
I found Cipher Three--I found my father--and I executed him so the Sith couldn't. He said he understood.
I wish there had been a way to spare him.
I'm sorry, Temple.
Don't apologize. He was a criminal, and we did our duty.
I never thought you'd go through with it. Why?
How could you?
Because I believe in the Empire.
Now if you'll excuse me, I'd like some time alone.
You can't defy the Sith and expect to survive.
He deserved it.
But he was hunted down and punished for keeping me a secret. Real justice would be turning myself in to the Sith.
What's done is done. Martyring yourself won't change it.
And also pointless.
No, and I don't want to die--not on Korriban.
Cipher Three made that choice for you.
This isn't your fault.
He started the lie. But I've kept it going for years.
You were born to be a Sith. You can't hide forever.
I would consider it.
I know.
I'm grateful for your help. We did the proper thing.
Yes, Ensign?
Sir, there's something you should know. I've been scanning Chiss frequencies--passing the time, checking low-security reports.
An old associate left this message where he knew I could find it--it's a hologram the Chiss intercepted from Korriban.
Play the message, please.
Let's hear it.
This "old associate" of yours--someone from the Defense Force?
Who sent you this message?
Yes. But the important thing is the message itself.
No one should know where you are, let alone be passing messages.
I don't like this.
I trust this person. And he thought I needed to see the hologram.
I have received the fugitive's location. Even he could not run forever. We must now find the Force sensitive he hid from us.
You need not send your agents. I'll make the former Cipher Three pay for his defiance myself.
Intelligence need no longer be involved. I will make Cipher Three pay for his defiance myself.
I'm... sorry, sir. If I knew this would be an issue, I would have told you earlier.
Cipher Three is my father. The Force sensitive he's hiding is me.
Do the Sith know of your relationship?
This could be trouble.
No. My father took precautions. He changed records, birth dates, even my name.
He's been on the run from the Sith all these years? Impressive.
He's done a good job.
I was a child. When the Sith made their rounds, my father made sure I was elsewhere. Then he disappeared.
You have my condolences. Anything else?
Sad, but unimportant.
The Sith will do worse than kill him. Torture, public display... he can't go through that. Not for me.
If you have a solution, I'm listening.
I'm open to suggestions.
An early warning could help him escape.
We can send word to him.
I'm not going to compound his treason.
Your father knew what he was doing when he betrayed the Sith.
He'll get what he deserves.
He deserves punishment--but not this.
I can find my father before Lord Darrok does--there are coordinates in the message. With your permission... I can give him a quick death.
You want to kill your own father?
You can't be serious.
I don't "want" any of this, but there isn't any other choice!
He saved your life. The least you can do is help him.
You have to rescue him.
I can't--I have to be better than him, I have to do my duty.
I won't be gone long. Besides, if I don't do something, your security could be compromised.
Be safe out there. Find your father and come back--and be careful of that Sith.
I'll wish you good luck.
I will. Thank you.
All right--go, if you must. But don't make any decisions until you've found your father.
Please consider mercy.
We'll see. Thank you.
Then your father must die.
You know what you have to do, Ensign. Get going.
You're getting ruthless. Good.
Yes, sir. I promise, sir--whatever happens, this won't come back on you.
What is it, Ensign?
Sir, remember I told you I completed the Intelligence training program?
Well, frankly, I'm a little embarrassed--and the rest of my numbers were very good--but I apparently forgot one of the final tests.
Exactly what test did you forget?
"Apparently"?
I'm sure you could convince me to forgive one tiny mistake.
[Flirt] We can let it slip....
Sir, I wouldn't feel right.
You didn't exactly go through the standard regimen.
I'm surprised it's only one.
I did the best I could, but something had to give.
I neglected to complete the interpersonal subversion examination. I'm supposed to be able to move and talk and act in a way that... holds the attention of my target.
It's a very delicate examination, as I understand.
What can I do to help you, Ensign?
Is there something I can do?
I'll have to pass judgment myself, then. Shall we find some privacy?
[Flirt] Let's go somewhere....
Certainly, sir.
Very few candidates ever master the art of seduction.
It's extremely difficult.
I imagine that's true, but I'd like to try.
I thought you might vet my skills in private and tell me if I'm adequately subversive.
I'm eager to see what you've learned.
Of course.
Come along, then.
Would you approach a real asset this way?
Charming, but not subtle.
Not if I thought he might say no. Are you coming?
So what do you think, sir? Have I learned to your satisfaction?
I find everything about you satisfying. I'm glad we met on Hoth.
I'm very fond of you, Ensign.
You've warmed me considerably. And I rather enjoy your company.
You were wonderful. But not many Imperials would be here with a Chiss.
You don't mind that I'm alien?
No. And I've never been fond like this of a Chiss before, but... I rather enjoy your company. I assume you don't mind.
I'd like to do this again, just to make sure.
I need to see more.
I'm sure we'll find the time. Just let me know when.
Back to the job.
You'll have to do better than that to impress me.
It was standard fare.
I see. Well, I'll let you know if I ever perfect my methods.
Right now, I need your focus on our mission.
Perhaps later.
Of course, sir, I didn't mean--another time, then.
Sir, I've been monitoring Chiss Defense Force frequencies; tracking ship movements in the Rim.
Nothing extraordinary, but I'd like your permission to investigate if something comes up--assuming you trust me solo.
You wouldn't be here if I couldn't count on you. Put your training to good use.
I trust your judgment.
Thank you, sir. I'll let you know if anything comes up.
What are you looking for out there?
Something you're expecting?
Anything to keep me busy. Monitor duty kept me sane on Hoth, and here I won't freeze to death if I leave my station, so...
I'll let you know if I find something, sir. Don't worry.
You obey your orders, and you do not take the initiative. Understood?
Don't even think about it.
Of course. I'll be sure to run everything past you.
Something I can help you with, Ensign?
I was hoping you could increase my security clearance, sir--at least long enough so I could know about my promotion.
What promotion are we talking about?
Your promotion?
The top secret one, sir. I can only assume it occurred.
I'd be happy to help, but there are forms to sign, background checks to run....
That process takes time...
I'm more patient than you'd expect.
I'm really not in the mood for this.
Get to the point, and fast.
Of course not.
I'm pleased to say that I've finished--as best I can--putting myself through the Imperial Intelligence training regimen. Save the psychological tests.
With your help, I'm now almost qualified to be here. Thank you.
You're a fine operative. You should be proud.
You've come a long way.
I am proud, sir. I thought you could tell.
If you have more questions, feel free to ask.
Glad I could assist.
I was taught the best operatives figure it out for themselves.
Trained or not, I decide when you're qualified to run missions.
You're no agent yet.
Then I'll just have to keep trying, sir.
You know, sir, the Chiss Defense Force has a term for when a subordinate is entangled with his or her superior officer.
It's considered an honorable and tragic state; if discovered, the lower-ranking officer is encouraged to go out in a blaze of glory.
You're not with the Defense Force anymore, and I'd rather you not martyr yourself.
I'd rather this not be tragic.
I was so hoping you'd say that.
Somehow that doesn't sound quite right.
Are you sure that's real?
This isn't a tradition I'm familiar with.
I've never heard of that.
It's possible Sergeant Thent was having fun at my expense.
Channels the emotions productively and gets rid of the problem. Interesting.
Not such a bad idea.
Your concern is always stirring, sir.
Of course, according to Imperial naval tradition, a captain is expected to dine with his closest associates--male or female--once a month. It's a show of loyalty.
Ensign, it would be my pleasure if you joined me for a meal.
Would you like to have dinner?
I'd enjoy that very much. I won't rush you, but somewhere planetside would be nice.
You're not serious, are you?
You're just playing with me...
I'm just reporting what I've been taught. Make of it what you will.
You're not in the military anymore. We have our own traditions here.
This isn't the navy.
And you'll have to let me participate at some point.
Oh--there is one other thing, sir, and I don't mean to pry, but... there won't be any trouble between you and Kaliyo. Correct?
I'm just not entirely clear on your relationship.
I care about Kaliyo, but we weren't meant to be. You and I, though, maybe we have a chance.
You're more important to me.
I'd like that. You need to break it to her, though.
I'm not stupid, agent. You want the kid, have a good time.
Just don't come crawling back when she hits her limit.
I'd like that. We'll talk later, alright?
I like you, Ensign--but Kaliyo's part of my life.
Kaliyo always comes first.
I see. Maybe it's a good thing we haven't had that dinner.
I hope you don't mind if I focus on our work for a while, sir.
There is no relationship between me and Kaliyo. Not anymore.
She's dead to me.
I see. I'm... sorry to hear that. But things will get better.
Get Kaliyo. I should've done this a while ago.
She's nuts; I'll tell her now.
Ah--yes, sir.
You're a freaking piece of work, agent.
You want her? Fantastic. Just leave me out from now on and don't get nostalgic.
Is everything... alright?
Kaliyo's tough. She won't be happy, but she'll get over it.
She'll be okay.
I'm sure she will. I'll give her some space.
No one's going to keep us apart.
It's just you and me now.
Thank you. I hope we deserve each other.
Fine. I'd like some time alone, please.
I'd rather not discuss it.
Yes, sir.
Sir, I just had a talk with Vector. Not something I do often, but I think I'm getting used to the eyes.
When I was a little girl, the only aliens I ever saw were the Kaas City slaves. Now we see stranger things every day.
There are benefits to a job like ours.
It's a fascinating life.
Shame we're not allowed to take pictures.
You must've had a sheltered childhood.
No other aliens at all?
I had the best childhood money could buy--and that includes a good shelter.
We're exposed to many foreign influences. Fight them and remain strong.
Don't forget who you are.
Yes, sir. I don't intend to forget that I'm Imperial.
Anyway, I want to get more combat practice in before tomorrow. Talk soon?
What's going on, Ensign?
Sir. Doctor Lokin's been filling in the gaps in my education. He has quite a few stories.
Here's what puzzles me--I've always been taught to respect the chain of command, and yet you... how does anyone control a field agent?
You're really perturbed by this. Are you that used to pure obedience?
Independence bothers you?
Yes, I am. And I don't think that's a bad thing.
The Empire expects its operatives to make command decisions from the front line. That doesn't work.
Placing an operative in the field is always a risk. If you don't trust someone's judgment, you don't send him out.
You can't control everything.
What sort of judgment, though? You can't make operational decisions from the front line.
Typically, you manipulate and blackmail your people so they can't go off task.
Keep the leash very short.
Whatever happened to "for Emperor and Empire"? You are joking....
Besides, if you don't know why you're doing what you're doing, how can you possibly make operational decisions?
Eventually, you stop relying on your handbook, and you put the good of the Empire first.
Imperial principal guides us.
I was hoping for something more concrete; maybe a numbered list?
All you can do is respond to each situation, right or wrong.
Sometimes you make mistakes.
And live with the consequences.
You're talking to the wrong person. I find orders get in the way.
You worry way too much.
If I'd only known we had that policy here....
I don't want to do wrong, sir. My father ignored an edict from the Sith, and instead of facing his punishment, he ran.
I won't repeat his mistake accidentally.
What did your father do that was so terrible?
Tell me what happened.
I'd rather not discuss it. Refusing to do his duty was enough.
Have a little faith in yourself. If the time comes, you'll make the right call.
I trust your judgment, Ensign.
It's nice to hear you say that, sir.
Don't ignore the Sith, don't commit treason, and it all works out. Clear?
Don't be as stupid as him.
Perfectly clear, sir.
I'll stop troubling you about this. Back to the job, then?
How can I help you, Ensign?
Personal question for you, sir, if you don't mind my asking.
When you have to win a man's affections over the course of a mission, does it bother you?
Are you worried about having to seduce an asset?
Why do you ask?
I'm not entirely certain.
I have a purely professional question for you, sir, if you don't mind my asking.
When you lie to a woman over the course of a mission, make her think you're interested... does it bother you?
Any reason you're "professionally" interested?
Why do you ask?
Getting close to our targets is one of the perks of this job.
I rather enjoy it.
You're a cad, sir.
I prefer methods with less collateral damage.
Seduction is a last resort.
Don't mistake me--I've been involved with plenty of the wrong men, but going in, there was always the chance they'd work out.
I don't know how I'd make that connection if I knew it wouldn't last, or if I had someone waiting back home.
Romance is an option, but so is negotiation; so is blackmail. Don't feel obligated.
There are always alternatives.
I appreciate that, sir. It's all just a bit muddled.
Don't put your life on hold in the name of duty.
Look for love where you can.
But duty always comes first, doesn't it?
At least I have my parents as an example. Happily married Cipher agents, so far as I ever knew.
I don't know how I'd handle living one life in the field and another back at home. It must be exhausting.
Don't let the work get in the way. There's room for romance, if you want it.
You can't be afraid of caring.
Do you want a woman in your life, sir? Or has experience taught you better?
Sometimes it's best to live in the moment--enjoy it while it lasts.
[Flirt] A fling can be fun.
Spoken like a true hedonist. So, I should abandon my dreams of romance?
That's a question we should talk about over dinner sometime. What do you say?
[Flirt] Let me show you.
That sounds lovely.
Have I ever mentioned what a pleasure you are?
[Flirt] You're adorable.
It might have come up.
For the record, we'd be defying all sorts of military protocols, and I won't be held responsible.
Close partners function best. I wouldn't worry about it.
Good operatives often bond.
We'll just have to risk our careers.
I'll take that chance.
Understood, sir. Then we have a lot to look forward to.
If we're going to do this, let's not be cloying about it.
Don't bore me, Ensign.
Yes, sir. As you like.
I enjoy your company, but you need to take these questions to someone else.
Don't get the wrong idea.
Right. Well--I'll leave you be then, sir. Thank you for your help.
Lust is a weapon, it's a tool of the trade.
Don't romanticize the work.
If you're going to depress me, sir, I'll have to stop asking questions.
Next thing you know, you'll tell me my parents' marriage was a sham. Two Ciphers under one roof....
I didn't know your family had such a history with the work.
Both your parents? Huh.
Well, somewhat, anyway.
That doesn't surprise me. Intelligence might've encouraged the partnership.
Sometimes agents bond well.
And isn't it lovely when our professional and personal lives meet?
If they really were happy, it's a rarity. More likely, it was a professional necessity.
It probably was a sham.
They made room enough for me. Until the Force got in the way.
Thank you for your honesty, sir. You won't regret these sessions.
Sir. Since our combat session went so well, I thought we might try something else.
Lessons in interpersonal manipulation and information extraction. Lecture one, entitled...?
You want me to teach you how to lie and manipulate people?
Are you serious about this?
You don't need a thug on your team, sir. I admire the Intelligence tradition, and I want to pull my weight.
Once they think they need you, they'll tell you anything.
"Earn their trust."
Descriptive name, sir. Is it always about need?
Give it up, Ensign. You're not undercover material.
You're not cut out for this.
So help me. I could be your partner if you'll let me.
When I first arrived at Zero Station, no one trusted me. I was the human Imperial who must have been a spy.
But I learned my way around, and once the Chiss accepted my competence, it was easy to make friends.
Not all your marks will be as pleasant as the Chiss.
It won't always be easy.
I'm not the only one who finds you charming.
[Flirt] People like you.
And yet I'm still here.
More seriously, though. I'm stuck somewhere, infiltrating a gang of spice dealers. How do I play it?
That's one of your strengths--people like you, and you can use that.
You're naturally charming.
So suppose we're separated during an operation against... pirates, say. How does your hand-trained operative play it?
Try making friends when your mark wants you dead.
That's hardly infiltration.
Yes, I see. And what would you suggest under those circumstances?
You blend into the background and wait for an opportunity. Don't stir the pot unless you know what you're in for.
Just watch and listen.
I'll happily leave that to you, then.
Lying can get messy. I prefer the direct approach.
Stick with force.
I've seen interrogations. Force can get messy, too.
I don't know what you think of my potential, sir, but I do appreciate your guidance. I've been deceiving people like an amateur for years.
Time I started doing it right.
We're not having this discussion, Ensign. Understand?
I'm not getting into this.
Yes, sir. Understood.
You said you wanted to talk?
Yes, sir. Ensign Raina Temple, formerly of the Chiss Expansionary Defense Force, reporting for combat drills.
I never said anything about combat drills.
I'm not sure I understand.
No, sir. If you had, I wouldn't need to bring it up.
I can show you a few things. What brings this on?
Combat drills? All right.
Do I look like someone who enjoys a playful approach to our work?
Don't get cute with me.
I take your point. It wasn't meant to offend.
Frankly, I need the practice. No one ever taught me covert maneuvers. If you've got time....
Grab your equipment. I'll find a private spot.
Let's get you into shape.
Thank you, sir.
You're just looking for an excuse to be alone with me.
[Flirt] I see how this is.
That's only one of many benefits. Are you coming?
If I didn't think you were capable, I wouldn't have you out there.
You've been doing fine.
That's kind of you to say, but would you bet your life on it? Come on....
...all right, I think I've sweat enough for one day.
Any last words of wisdom for your freshly transferred ensign?
Never let anything distract you. No one can compensate for your errors.
Above all, stay focused.
I'm confident it isn't so dire, but I take your point.
There are some things you have to learn for yourself.
I can't tell all my secrets...
And you can't give me examples?
Murder is your job, and hesitation could cost you your life. Remember that.
Never show mercy.
Sir. I've never been squeamish about fighting the enemy.
You know, my father used to come home from exercises freshly scarred. I was twelve before I realized his "training drills" were Intelligence operations.
He was captured twice, but he wouldn't let me worry, no matter how bad it got.
I didn't know your father was part of Intelligence.
So he was an agent.
I thought I'd mentioned it. He was a Cipher.
You two must have been close.
You sound fond of him.
Oh, I adored him. He gave me a pet felinx for my birthday--that'll melt any girl's heart.
The best operatives don't get caught, let alone more than once.
He sounds sloppy.
I wouldn't worry. He's no longer in the Empire's service.
Thank you for the lesson. A few more, and I'll be infiltrating enemy camps with the best of them.
Find another sparring partner, and don't bother me with trivia.
Go get someone else to help.
Of course, sir. I'll do what I can.
I'd like a moment in private with you on the ship.
Could we speak for a few moments? Whenever you have the chance.
This isn't the best time to talk.
You're getting ruthless. Good.
I can get right on that.
I think this discussion can wait.
Ready to go, sir.
Do you have a plan, sir?
At your side, sir.
Now, if you don't mind--I should return to work.
